str2: And, even, also, namely.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Dust. From the base of koniao and ornumi; pulverulence.
From out, out from among, from, suggesting from the interior outwards. A primary preposition denoting origin, from, out.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 2nd Person Plural
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
A city, the inhabitants of a city. Probably from the same as polemos, or perhaps from polus; a town.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.

parse: Verb - Aorist Participle Passive - Accusative Masculine Singular
str2: From kolla; to glue, i.e. to stick.
A primary preposition; to or into, of place, time, or purpose; also in adverbial phrases.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Dative 1st Person Plural
str2: I, the first-person pronoun. A primary pronoun of the first person I.
The foot. A primary word; a 'foot'.

word: we wipe off as a testimony
parse: Verb - Present Indicative Middle - 1st Person Plural
str2: To wipe off, wipe clean; mid: I wipe myself off. Middle voice from apo and masso; to scrape away.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Dative 2nd Person Plural
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
However, nevertheless, but, except that, yet. From pleion; moreover, i.e. Albeit, save that, rather, yet.

parse: Verb - Present Imperative Active - 2nd Person Plural
str2: A prolonged form of a primary verb; to 'know' in a great variety of applications and with many implications.
This; he, she, it.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From basileus; properly, royalty, i.e. rule, or a realm.
A deity, especially the supreme Divinity; figuratively, a magistrate; by Hebraism, very.

parse: Verb - Perfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: Trans: I bring near; intrans: I come near, approach. From eggus; to make near, i.e. approach.
